title: 113_s1844
content: The "Military Retirement Restoration Act" repeals Section 403 of the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2013 and treats foreign corporations managed and controlled in the United States as domestic corporations. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 treats certain corporations managed and controlled in the United States as domestic for income tax purposes, regardless of their original classification. The amendment to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 treats certain corporations managed and controlled in the United States as domestic for income tax purposes, regardless of their original classification. A corporation is described as regularly traded on an established securities market or having aggregate gross assets of $50,000,000 or more. The corporation must meet specific criteria to be treated as described in the paragraph, including not being regularly traded on an established securities market and having aggregate gross assets of less than $50,000,000. The Secretary can grant a waiver to the corporation. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to determine when the management and control of a corporation is primarily within the United States, focusing on executive officers and senior management. The regulations will determine the management and control of a corporation primarily in the United States, focusing on executive officers and senior management, including individuals from other corporations in the same chain. The regulations will determine that a corporation's management and control in the United States is based on assets primarily managed for investors, with investment decisions made in the U.S. These amendments will apply to taxable years starting two years after the enactment of the Act.
